comment.author: 93914123@N00
comment._content: They're preserving the titles of the photos as they were titled when they were taken. It's the Library of Congress historically documenting (and sharing with us) pieces of history. While that time period, and the subject matter is certainly sad and distasteful, I think it would be terrible if the LOC cleaned up the titles and other information to appeal to our modern sensibilities. It's much more important to get an accurate representation of history, imho. But I certainly understand where you're coming from- it was a terrible situation for the government to even conceive of internment camps, let alone put them into practice.

comment.author: 72659997@N00
comment._content: I agree with both Sakura and Jade.  It bothers me that they used "war emergency evacuation," though I understand the user posting it as the original piece.  This is the first time I've ever heard it being documented as "war emergency evacuation."  My grandfather was at Tulelake as well as other relatives, aunts and uncles, while my father served in the Army for American "freedom."  My grandfather was in the country for 40 years.  It's sad because this part of history really messed up the lives of these families.  When my grandpa got out all that was left was an anvil, I remember growing up seeing my father use it on the farm.  Tule Lake Committee is having the annual pilgrimage July 3.

comment.author: 72659997@N00
comment._content: I think the person recording the image into the LOC isn't informed, so it was recorded as such. I have family records and no record that I've read ever had "war emergency evacuation" only War Relocation Authority [WRA] and Tule Lake Segregation Camp or Internment Camp. It wasn't an emergency evacuation because it took several months to have the Japanese removed from their homes. Executive Order 9066 doesn't even state "war emergency evacuation," so I think that is a misnomer. Executive Order 9066 : historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5154

comment.author: 86371462@N00
comment._content:
History should be preserved as it was originally recorded. It is then up to historians to interpret the raw data. Think of it like financial data. The data should be preserved as it is. To change it would be dishonest. However, the data is then interpreted.

in this case, we look at the raw historical data as it is, and then we interpret it for ourselves. This is the best way.
